author: By Matt Stevens
title: Oklahoma’s Booming Film Industry Has Texas’ Attention
description: To attract movie and television production, states must try to offer the best incentives. The competition drives spending on Hollywood subsidies ever higher.
content: For a very brief moment, Taylor Sheridan’s hit television series starring Sylvester Stallone had the working title “Kansas City Mob.” But at the time, Missouri had no state funding for film subsidies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Kuo
title: The Gang That Preyed on America’s Small Museums
description: No one mistook them for cat burglars, but authorities say the crew spent two decades pilfering, and in some cases destroying, art and sports treasures, including Yogi Berra’s championship rings.
content: The first burglary was in 1999 at Keystone College in Factoryville, Pa. One of the gang, authorities said, sneaked onto the campus, smashed some glass display cases and walked off with memorabilia, including a baseball jersey once worn by Christy Mathewson, the legendary pitcher.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquín and Amanda Holpuch
title: Southwest Plane Makes Emergency Landing After Boeing Engine Cover Falls Off
description: The plane returned safely to Denver on Sunday after the crew reported that the cover came apart during takeoff and struck a wing flap. No injuries were reported.
content: A Southwest Airlines flight safely returned to Denver International Airport on Sunday after the engine cover of a Boeing 737-800 fell off during takeoff and struck the wing flap, the Federal Aviation Administration said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paulette Perhach
title: Guarding Royal Families for $1,000 a Day: Inside Executive Protection Jobs
description: How three women trained to work in jobs protecting prominent families and ultra-high-net-worth individuals.
content: Monica Duperon Rodriguez welled up with feelings of awe when she stepped off a charter flight onto the Serengeti in Africa for a job assignment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King
title: Democratic Group to Spend $186 Million Aiming to Win Back House Majority
description: In an interview on Sunday, the House Majority PAC president described the group’s investment as part of “an offensive strategy” for this election year.
content: House Majority PAC, the Democratic super PAC allied with Representative Hakeem Jeffries of New York, the House minority leader, said on Sunday that it would spend $186 million on television and digital advertisements for this year’s elections — the largest early investment in the group’s history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Zipkin
title: Planning to Combine Business and Leisure Travel? You’re Not Alone.
description: As employees increasingly add leisure time to their business trips, companies are trying to figure out where their duty of care obligations begin and end.
content: On a Sunday in late January, Melinda Buchmann, who lives in Florida and supervises client relations for RevShoppe, a 30-person remote company advising organizations on sales techniques and strategies, arrived in Banff, Alberta, to help set up a four-day company meeting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Anticipation and Anxiety Build Ahead of the Total Solar Eclipse
description: Across parts of the United States, Mexico and Canada, would-be eclipse-gazers are on the move for what could be a once-in-a-lifetime event.
content: Millions of people will tilt their heads skyward on Monday, marveling at a total solar eclipse. The moon will cross the sun and block its light for a few fleeting moments, creating a communal celestial experience that will not again be so accessible to people in the United States, Canada or Mexico for decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Hamby
title: Health Insurers’ Lucrative, Little-Known Alliance: 5 Takeaways
description: A private-equity-backed firm has helped drive down payments to medical providers, drive up patients’ bills and earn billions for insurers.
content: Large health insurers are working with a little-known data company to boost their profits, often at the expense of patients and doctors, a New York Times investigation found. A private-equity-backed firm called MultiPlan has helped drive down payments to medical providers and drive up patients’ bills, while earning billions of dollars in fees for itself and insurers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Carding at a Bar
description: Peter Gordon rises to the occasion.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: April 7, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, April 7, 2024.
content: An article on Friday about simultaneous terrorist attacks by a separatist group in Iran misidentified the location of Sistan and Baluchestan Province, where the attacks occurred. It is in the southeast, not the southwest, of Iran.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: Kristen Wiig Hosts ‘S.N.L.’ With Help From a Few Famous Friends
description: Matt Damon, Ryan Gosling, Paul Rudd, Jon Hamm, Martin Short, Paula Pell, Fred Armisen and Will Forte all turned out to help induct Wiig into the show’s Five-Timers Club.
content: Despite her claim that her fifth time hosting “Saturday Night Live” would not be celebrated with a parade of celebrity guests and other “S.N.L.” alums wishing her well, Kristen Wiig turned her opening monologue into just that as she marked this milestone with help from Paul Rudd, Matt Damon, Ryan Gosling and other famous pals.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘The Late Hour Meant Taking a Cab Home, Something I Mostly Avoid’
description: A scruffy driver’s musical surprise, an unexpected lift and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrina Miller
title: Can’t Find Eclipse Glasses? Here’s What to Do.
description: You can watch a projection of the eclipse using some common household items.
content: Reliable paper-framed glasses are by far the most popular option for safely watching the total solar eclipse on Monday. But they’ve gotten more difficult to find in some places ahead of the event.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Albert Heath, Jazz Drum Virtuoso, Is Dead at 88
description: He accompanied stars like John Coltrane and worked frequently with his brothers. “I’ve always thought I was a master,” he once said. Few disagreed.
content: Albert Heath, a virtuoso jazz drummer who collaborated with luminaries like John Coltrane, Thelonious Monk, Nina Simone and Herbie Hancock; performed and recorded with his older brothers, Percy and Jimmy; and for a few years played alongside Percy in one of the great jazz ensembles, the Modern Jazz Quartet, died on Wednesday in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Tom Bodkin Believes in Form, Function and the Enduring Elegance of Design
description: After a 46-year career at The New York Times, Mr. Bodkin is retiring from his role as chief creative officer.
content: On a sunny Monday in March, Tom Bodkin strolled through the sloping fields of his backyard, 150 acres of grass, quarries and forest, home to totems of his passions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Hamby
title: In Battle Over Health Care Costs, Private Equity Plays Both Sides
description: As medical practices owned by private equity firms fuel overbilling, a payment tool also backed by such investors helps insurers boost their profits.
content: Insurance companies have long blamed private-equity-owned hospitals and physician groups for exorbitant billing that drives up health care costs. But a tool backed by private equity is helping insurers make billions of dollars and shift costs to patients.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Balarama Heller
title: My Faith Forbade Eclipse Gazing. Now It Inspires My Art.
description: An artist ponders how his religious childhood affects the art he now creates around eclipse imagery.
content: As a child growing up in the Hare Krishna community in the United States, I was forbidden to be outside during a solar eclipse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Trump Fund-Raiser Rakes In More Than $50.5 Million, Campaign Says
description: The event, hosted at the Palm Beach home of the hedge-fund billionaire John Paulson, follows a concerted effort by the Trump campaign to close the money gap with Democrats.
content: For several hours on Saturday evening, drivers on a typically scenic stretch of Palm Beach, Fla., had their views of the coast obscured by a line of luxury vehicles whose owners were mingling inside a mansion across the road.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan Burton
title: Her Husband Signed Up for the Military. She Didn’t.
description: In “The Wives,” Simone Gorrindo tells the story of joining a behind-the-scenes sorority — and how it changed her.
content: “Sometimes I think about joining the military,” Simone Gorrindo’s boyfriend, Andrew, tells her early in their relationship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Ralkowski
title: Larry David, Philosopher King
description: Larry David’s long-running show was hilarious, but it also revolved around a complex view of modern philosophy.
content: “Curb Your Enthusiasm,” the HBO comedy series created by and starring Larry David, debuted way back in 1999 and comedy, television and the world have all changed significantly since. Yet somehow “Curb,” which comes to an end tonight after 12 seasons, remains as relevant as ever. How can that be?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Segal
title: Q: Who Found a Way to Crack the U.K.’s Premier Quiz Show?
description: Brandon Blackwell, a 30-year-old from Queens, helped turn London’s Imperial College into a “University Challenge” powerhouse.
content: Brandon Blackwell sits in his apartment in the Jamaica section of Queens, training with a collection of 30,000 homemade flash cards the way weight lifters train with barbells. Each card contains an obscure fact about the world. Which country is home to Lake Assal, the largest salt reserve on earth? (Djibouti).  Which metal is smelted using the Hall-Héroult process? (Aluminum).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mary Pilon
title: Can Minor League Baseball Survive Its Real Estate Problems?
description: The fight over a new stadium for the Eugene Emeralds highlights a wider challenge for cheaper alternatives to big-league live sports.
content: Ed Willson has a jar filled with dirt sitting on his desk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 301
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gershon Baskin
title: What Netanyahu Must Do to Bring Home the Hostages
description: It is evident in everything he has done that their safety is not his top priority.
content: If the Israeli prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, were serious about securing the release of all the hostages in Gaza, they would have been home long ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon
title: Israel’s Troop Withdrawal Raises Questions About Its Plans in Gaza
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has promised an invasion of the southern city of Rafah, where more than a million people are seeking shelter.
content: The Israeli military said it withdrew a division of ground troops from southern Gaza on Sunday, raising questions about its plans as the war reached the six-month mark.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Kelly
title: Princess Reema, Bandar’s Daughter, Navigates Rough Waters in Washington
description: The Saudi ambassador to the United States, the daughter of a storied figure in the kingdom’s diplomacy, is trying to steer relations at a difficult time.
content: She attended the elite Holton-Arms School for girls in the suburbs outside Washington. On weekends she strolled with friends on shopping trips through the Tysons Corner Center mall in Northern Virginia. Three American secretaries of state — Colin L. Powell, James A. Baker and Madeleine Albright — were regular guests in her parents’ home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Why States Have Spent Billions Subsidizing Hollywood
description: Inside the costly competition to attract TV and film shoots.
content: State governments use our tax dollars to build roads, fund schools and provide health care. In 38 states, they also ship money off to a high-gloss private industry: Hollywood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Casey Benjamin, Free-Spirited Saxophonist, Dies at 45
description: A musical voyager who wouldn’t be limited by genre, style or even instrument, he brought exuberance to the Robert Glasper Experiment and other groups.
content: Casey Benjamin, who brought colorfully expansive saxophone flourishes to the Grammy-winning Robert Glasper Experiment and added rich layers of texture to recordings by Solange, A Tribe Called Quest and many others, died on March 30 in Maryland. He was 45.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Tennant-Moore
title: A Frenchwoman’s Midlife Sexual Awakening
description: “Playboy,” an autobiographical novel by the writer Constance Debré, follows a woman who left her husband and job in search of pleasure.
content: The trilogy of autobiographical novels by the French writer Constance Debré could be described — reductively — as a challenging yet empowering coming-out journey, the story of a middle-aged woman who lost everything to find herself. But Debré has no interest in portraying life as a series of events in a familiar psychological progression. She is done with the kinds of books she read as a child, “stories of a world that lived in stories,” as she writes in “Playboy” — the first book in the trilogy and the second to be translated into English by Holly James. Turning our experiences into tidy stories “ends up warping our understanding of life and what we expect from it.” The point of literature, for Debré, is to force the reader into immediate, visceral reality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Monday Briefing: Israel Pulls Some Troops from Southern Gaza
description: Also, Mexico and Nicaragua severed diplomatic relations with Ecuador.
content: The Israeli military said it withdrew a division of ground troops from southern Gaza yesterday. The move raised questions about its plans as the war reached the six-month mark — Israeli media reported that the withdrawal meant there were no Israeli troops actively maneuvering in southern Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard and Bilal Shbair
title: To Battle Wartime Hunger, Gazans Turn to a Humble Leafy Green
description: Palestinians have long gathered and cooked khobeza, a spinach-like wild plant that sprouts after rains. Now, it has become a lifeline.
content: As the Israeli military campaign to destroy Hamas pummeled his neighborhood in northern Gaza, reducing buildings to rubble and forcing residents to flee, the Palestinian laborer realized that he was running out of food.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: ‘Gladiator Politics’ Dominate Election Season in Polarized South Korea
description: This week’s parliamentary elections are widely seen as a referendum on both President Yoon Suk Yeol and his archrival, Lee Jae-myung, the opposition leader.
content: The elections are ostensibly about the 300 seats in Parliament, but when South Koreans go to the polls on Wednesday, they will also be signaling support for one of two leaders who are locked in what is known here as “gladiator politics.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Phoebe Zerwick, Samantha Desz, Jack D'Isidoro, Aaron Esposito, Anna Diamond, Emma Kehlbeck, Sophia Lanman and Sharon Kearney
title: The Sunday Read: ‘What Deathbed Visions Teach Us About Living’
description: Researchers are documenting a phenomenon that seems to help the dying, as well as those they leave behind.
content: Chris Kerr was 12 when he first observed a deathbed vision. His memory of that summer in 1974 is blurred, but not the sense of mystery he felt at the bedside of his dying father. Throughout Kerr’s childhood in Toronto, his father, a surgeon, was too busy to spend much time with his son, except for an annual fishing trip they took, just the two of them, to the Canadian wilderness. Gaunt and weakened by cancer at 42, his father reached for the buttons on Kerr’s shirt, fiddled with them and said something about getting ready to catch the plane to their cabin in the woods. “I knew intuitively, I knew wherever he was, must be a good place because we were going fishing,” Kerr told me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Segal
title: “University Challenge” Questions: How Do You Stack Up?
description: Our adaptation of a few of the questions that Imperial College got right in the semi-final game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: A C.I.A. Black Site Remains a Touchy Subject for Lithuania
description: Despite rulings in European courts saying the Baltic country was home to a secret prison, the issue has been shrouded in official secrecy in a nation closely allied with the United States.
content: First came containers loaded with equipment for a secluded property under renovation on the edge of the forest. It had housed a horseback riding academy and a cafe, but was being reconfigured for a mysterious enterprise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anderson Tepper
title: You Know Marlon James and Edwidge Danticat. Now Meet Astrid Roemer.
description: Roemer’s books bring Suriname, on the South American Caribbean coast, to the world. Her 2019 novel, “Off-White,” will be released in English this month.
content: For many readers in the United States, the literature of the Caribbean is a familiar one: Take Marlon James, Edwidge Danticat and Junot Díaz, for starters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Thirty Years After a Genocide in Rwanda, Painful Memories Run Deep
description: The Central African country is marking the anniversary of a monthslong rampage by militiamen that killed some 800,000 people.
content: When the marauding militiamen arrived at her door on that morning in April 1994, Florence Mukantaganda knew there was nowhere to run.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon, Patrick Kingsley, Ephrat Livni and Matt Stevens
title: Israel Withdraws Troops From Southern Gaza as War Hits 6-Month Mark
description: With the conflict at an apparent impasse, international mediators were gathering in Cairo with hopes of brokering a temporary cease-fire.
content: The Israeli military said Sunday that it had withdrawn a division of ground troops from the southern Gaza Strip, as international mediators gathered with hopes of brokering a temporary cease-fire six months into a war that has now become the longest involving Israel since the 1980s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Dias and Stella Blackmon
title: Gazing Skyward, and Awaiting a Moment of Awe
description: Millions of people making plans to be in the path of the solar eclipse on Monday know it will be awe-inspiring. What is that feeling?
content: The moment she saw the sun, something inside Julie McKelvey changed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: Why These New Yorkers’ Favorite Soccer Team Is in Denmark: They Own It.
description: Some people splurge on vacations, fancy shoes and motorcycles. A group of dozens of friends, neighbors and co-workers decided to try something better (or maybe worse).
content: One Sunday morning last month, several dozen American soccer fans gathered inside a Brooklyn bar to cheer on a middling, minor league club from Denmark.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer, Reid J. Epstein and Katie Glueck
title: How Gaza Protesters Are Challenging Democratic Leaders
description: From President Biden to the mayors of small cities, Democrats have been trailed by demonstrators who are complicating the party’s ability to campaign in an election year.
content: In Detroit, a congressman’s holiday party devolved into chaos and a broken nose after demonstrators protesting the war in Gaza appeared with bullhorns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Marsh
title: Before ‘S-Town’ Made Him Famous, Clock Lovers Knew Him Well
description: John B. McLemore, the brilliant and quirky star of the hit podcast “S-Town,” is the center of a show highlighting his work in the art of clock restoration.
content: John B. McLemore, a profanely outspoken, brilliant and troubled restorer of antique clocks, emerged a national figure in 2017 with the podcast “S-Town.” As a horologist — a repairer of devices that measure time — he restored intricate and rare pieces in a workshop at his family homestead in rural western Alabama.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: Israel Is Making the Same Mistake America Made in Iraq
description: The Israel Defense Forces’ military challenge is inseparable from its humanitarian obligations.
content: As the war in Gaza reaches its six-month mark, I’m getting a disturbing sense of déjà vu. Israel is facing many of the same challenges that America faced in Iraq, and it is making many of the same mistakes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liset Cruz
title: At Rally for Hostages, Some Boo When Congressman Calls for Gaza Aid
description: A speech by Jerrold Nadler, a long-serving Jewish Democrat and supporter of Israel, was met with a mixed response at a New York rally calling for the release of hostages in Gaza.
content: Representative Jerrold Nadler of New York was booed on Sunday at a demonstration in Manhattan calling for the release of hostages held by Hamas after he encouraged attendees to also push for humanitarian aid for Palestinians in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: In Milwaukee, Restaurants and Venues Worry of Seeing Limited R.N.C. Boost
description: In Chicago, venues are booking fast for the Democratic convention in August. But Milwaukee, host of the Republican convention, is wondering if customers will come.
content: Dan Jacobs, a contestant on the newest season of “Top Chef,” is having a national star turn with his soups, cheese treats and elevated snacks — and his open struggle with a rare degenerative disease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Michael Gold
title: Trump, at Fund-Raiser, Says He Wants Immigrants From ‘Nice’ Countries
description: At rallies, Donald Trump frequently laments migrants from a list of countries from Africa, Asia and the Middle East as he stokes fears around the surge at the border.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump, speaking at a multimillion-dollar fund-raiser on Saturday night, lamented that people were not immigrating to the United States from “nice” countries “like Denmark” and suggested that his well-heeled dinner companions were temporarily safe from undocumented immigrants nearby, according to an attendee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Man Arrested After Fire Set Outside Bernie Sanders’s Vermont Office
description: Prosecutors and the police did not identify a possible motive for the fire, which was started on Friday. No one was injured.
content: The authorities in Vermont arrested a man they said used an accelerant and a lighter to start a fire on Friday outside of Senator Bernie Sanders’s office in Burlington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: Happy 20th Anniversary, Gmail. I’m Sorry I’m Leaving You.
description: Hey, there’s a better way to do email.
content: There is no end of theories for why the internet feels so crummy these days. The New Yorker blames the shift to algorithmic feeds. Wired blames a cycle in which companies cease serving their users and begin monetizing them. The M.I.T. Technology Review blames ad-based business models. The Verge blames search engines. I agree with all these arguments. But here’s another: Our digital lives have become one shame closet after another.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Diamond
title: Grunge: A Dull Date, the Sound of Seattle, a ‘Time Capsule’
description: The New York Times has a long and complicated history with the word grunge. Let’s get down and dingy in it.
content: The New York Times and “grunge” go way back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Hamby
title: Insurers Reap Hidden Fees by Slashing Payments. You May Get the Bill.
description: A little-known data firm helps health insurers make more when less of an out-of-network claim gets paid. Patients can be on the hook for the difference.
content: Weeks after undergoing heart surgery, Gail Lawson found herself back in an operating room. Her incision wasn’t healing, and an infection was spreading.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: The Secret to These Shrimp Tacos Is Worcestershire
description: These tacos marry seafood with poblano chiles, diced onions and melted cheese on flour tortillas
content: Good morning. It’s skinned-knuckle season, the time of the year that’s all about stuck bolts and crushed washers and hydraulic fluid and bottom paint, sacrificial zincs and ceramic wax — old boats coaxed back to health so they can run us to the fishing grounds, so we can cast flies to bass.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich
title: Biden and Japan’s Leader Look to Bind Ties to Outlast Them Both
description: Hovering over a state visit to Washington is the possibility of a swing in American foreign policy if Donald Trump returns to the White House.
content: When President Biden welcomes Japan’s prime minister, Fumio Kishida, to Washington this week for a visit highlighted by the pomp of a state dinner, there will be an inescapable subtext to all the ceremony: Both leaders are in a fight to keep their jobs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melena Ryzik
title: Rachel McAdams Is Not Afraid of the Dark
description: The actress makes her Broadway debut in “Mary Jane” as the single mother of a seriously ill child. She views her acting choices as expanding her orbit.
content: From the outside, you wouldn’t know that Rachel McAdams, the thoughtfully charming star of blockbuster rom-coms, rom-drams, a Marvel franchise and the Oscar-winning “Spotlight,” has been wondering about death.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Schiff
title: America Was Once the Country Begging Richer Allies for Help
description: The logic of foreign entanglement was the same then as now.
content: Even before they declared their independence, it was clear to the American colonies that in their struggle against Great Britain they would need a wealthy benefactor. The colonies were desperately short of men, money and materiel. There was little by way of an American Navy, and barely an engineer on the continent. In 1776, the most gifted orator in Congress called for a declaration not by choice but by necessity, “as the only means by which foreign alliance can be obtained.” In that light, our founding document nearly qualifies as an SOS.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Homecoming
description: A single photo captures a moment of setback for families who had tried for a better life.
content: For years, hundreds of thousands of Afghans fleeing the turmoil of war crossed the border into Pakistan, hoping to start over again. Many of them succeeded in doing so.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Missing ‘1923’ Actor, Cole Brings Plenty, Is Found Dead
description: Mr. Brings Plenty, 27, was found dead in Kansas days after his family reported him missing. Officials did not provide a cause of death.
content: Cole Brings Plenty, an actor in the television series “1923,” was found dead on Friday in Kansas after his family reported him missing earlier in the week, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: The Perilous Existence of a Hamptons Day Laborer
description: In the shadow of opulent mansions, workmen spend their winters living in the woods. Julio Florencio Teo Gomez was one of them.
content: Early in the evening of Dec. 30, Julio Florencio Teo Gomez, a carpenter from Guatemala City who had shifted around different living situations on Long Island for more than a decade, went looking for money he was owed for a job he had completed before the holidays. Like so many other day laborers operating in the far reaches of Long Island, he had found the work at a roundup one morning in the parking lot of the 7-Eleven in Southampton. Throughout the final week of the year, he visited the lot several times in the late afternoons, when painters and millworkers, handymen and others in the building trades are dropped off at the end of the workday. He hoped to find the contractor who had neglected to pay him and collect what he was due.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Thinning of Oprah Winfrey
description: Her influence about weight and dieting and its objectives runs deep. Also: Unplugged from social media; keeping rodents away; ushering in spring.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Mahler
title: Is Corporate America in Denial About Trump?
description: Despite his populist promises, many bigwigs are keeping the faith that it couldn’t really happen here.
content: There was anxiety in the thin mountain air when the planet’s economic leaders gathered in January at Davos for the 54th meeting of the World Economic Forum. Donald Trump had just trounced Nikki Haley in the Iowa caucuses, all but securing the Republican nomination for president. Haley was reliable, a known quantity. A resurgent Trump, on the other hand, was more worrying.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Inside an Insurer’s Debate About Fees
description: Internal emails show UnitedHealthcare employees grappling with complaints about high fees. When one executive suggested limiting the amount charged New England Motor Freight, a colleague resisted.
content: Internal emails show UnitedHealthcare employees grappling with complaints about high fees. When one executive suggested limiting the amount charged New England Motor Freight, a colleague resisted.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Fact Check: An Explanation of Benefits
description: Insurers sometimes suggest that a medical provider agreed to a lower payment, even when it’s not so. This patient was billed the amount that Cigna identified as savings.
content: Insurers sometimes suggest that a medical provider agreed to a lower payment, even when it’s not so. This patient was billed the amount that Cigna identified as savings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Hamby, Claire Hogan and James Surdam
title: Our Reporter on a Hidden Health Insurance Alliance
description: A little-known data firm helps health insurers earn more when less of an out-of-network claim gets paid. Patients can be on the hook for the difference.
content: A little-known data firm helps health insurers earn more when less of an out-of-network claim gets paid. Patients can be on the hook for the difference.
source.name: The New York Times
